title: Tuesday, 3rd April, 2018

Soundbuy Morning
ppallav morning

vonB Morning - not so good far!

BE11:12am

How to read this? There's the obvious way, which is to say that it's probably enough for the CMA.

BE11:13am

And there's the oblique way, which is to say that Disney/Fox probably wouldn't have bothered unless they're going to bid again to match Comcast.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

That's Liberum's reading of it.

BE11:14am

We think two factors point to a revised bid. Firstly, we see the comment from Sky that "As the regulatory process remains ongoing, shareholders are advised to take no action at this stage. The Independent Directors of Sky are mindful of their fiduciary duties and remain focused on maximising value for Sky shareholders" as somewhat of a coded signal to Sky shareholders not to accept the Comcast bid as there may be a counter-offer coming through from Fox (and, by implication, Disney). Secondly, Fox must have gained approval from Disney to offer this remedy to the CMA.

The news that Sky Italia seems to have settled its long-running fight with Mediaset in the Italian Pay-TV market also makes Sky more valuable to a bidder, given it makes the prospects in Italy more attractive.

Soundbuy @RA - my wife expressed the same sentiment just this am - surprised he hadn't been already.........
Miss Piggy @RA: no life threats against POTUS please, or anyone for that matter.

BE11:22am

We expect more chatter out of the White House on Amazon throughout Trump's time in office. We, however, believe that little will change which has the potential to negatively impact Amazon's growth trajectory. Specifically, we find it unlikely that the Post Office will materially raise rates for Amazon deliveries, given Amazon would likely shift to alternative shipping options (perhaps both internal and external) and, as is the topic of this research note, we believe sales tax collection changes would have limited impact on consumer use of Amazon and could actually help Amazon's relative competitive positioning in domestic ecommerce. Maintain OW & $1,650 PT on AMZN.

Badger @RA The Washington Post has a point by point rebuttal of DT's ramblings on amazon.

And there's a survey!

RA @badger, ill check it our thank you
BE11:23am

We surveyed 2,000 U.S. consumers and asked them what is most important to them
when shopping online. We found that only 5% of Americans see sales tax amount as
a critical factor when deciding where to buy. Other components, such as shipping &
returns, product selection and website familiarity rank significantly higher for nearly all in our survey. In other words, even if there are changes to how Amazon collects sales tax in the U.S., our survey points to a very small impact on the core retail business.

Electric Dragon Also there's a good argument that Amazon is the only thing keeping USPS afloat.

BE11:28am

Apple Inc. is planning to use its own chips in Mac computers beginning as early as 2020, replacing processors from Intel Corp., according to people familiar with the plans.

The initiative, code named Kalamata, is still in the early developmental stages, but comes as part of a larger strategy to make all of Apple’s devices -- including Macs, iPhones, and iPads -- work more similarly and seamlessly together, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private information. The project, which executives have approved, will likely result in a multi-step transition.

Waterloo Long held view that Amazon is a dangerous company. Decimating high streets, draining local tax revenues, destroying some business sectors and providing low skilled and souless jobs with no community.

BE11:30am

Apple trying to in-source, however, if you need Windows, you need x86. The
press has reported for years that Apple will switch from Intel processors to internal CPUs, but Apple is still 100% Intel. We doubt this will change as the memory and processing requirements of Windows make using an ARM processor a miserable experience given the ARM processor capabilities are so far below x86 and struggle to be backwards-compatible and effectively function with the myriad of device drivers in a PC.

Miss Piggy Amazon is a force for good, that destroys entrenched comercial high street landlord's monopolies, eliminates the waste of shop window dressing. @waterloo re taxes, employees still pay tax, taxes on business can often be seen to be double taxation because dividends gets taxed as well.

wayneJ The rumour last yr was that Apple going to adopt Qualcomm's ARM based processor that can interpret Intel code. The only minor issue I see with that is the power consumption of running CISC code on a RISC architecture....hmmmm; but then again WallStreet technology analysis struggles with technology.

We estimate that Apple accounts for roughly $3 billion, or 4.5%, of INTC 2020E revenue and $0.20 of Intel 2020E EPS. Since we believe that ARM CPUs can replace Intel only in the lowest performance 10% of notebook sales in the best case for Apple due to the myriad of inherent difficulties, we believe the maximum downside risk from in-house CPUs is $0.02 to INTC 2020 EPS

The least well-perceived value in Spotify is its future role in ‘discovery’. With 200 petabytes of data on 150m music lovers’ preferences, Spotify is uniquely positioned to market what consumers will want . . . We estimate music promoters currently spend over $2.5bn per annum on advertising and marketing. This figure will grow in an expanding and ever noisier market, so that this second side of the ‘two-sided’ business model could account for well over 20 per cent of Spotify gross profit by 2022.

BE11:44am

We are initiating coverage on Spotify Technology with a BUY rating and
a price target of $175. The company has a compelling value proposition—leveraging its scale and technology infrastructure to create a superior experience for consumers and content creators. As investors look for valuation parameters, we expect focus will turn to the success of a similarly positioned company, Netflix, as an indicator of potential sentiment. As such, we expect investors will largely be biased positively on Spotify shares.

BornCynic Gillian Tett was on the box over Easter - the CNN documentary "the 80's". The program showed an 80's TV news clip "Donald Trump has said that he could negotiate a nuclear disarmament treaty"...........
TKZ @BE yet INTC still looks expansive even after near 8% decline yesterday. Should go low 30s for me to tempt.
TKZ get tempted I mean.
BE11:45am

And valuation ....

BE11:45am

Valuation: Our $175 price target is a blend of our DCF and sum-of-the-parts valuations. Spotify’s focus on creating a virtuous cycle for consumers and artists and using technology to create curated experiences evokes a Netflix-like promise of significant global penetration potential. Similar to our Netflix valuation, we use a DCF analysis given the still early investment phase that the company is in. We believe the DCF valuation best reflects the long-term potential value creation. Our DCF valuation uses a 10.1% WACC and a 4.0% terminal growth rate. Note that in our terminal year calculation, we assume that working capital becomes a modest drag on FCF compared to the significant contribution that it has made in the past two years. Furthermore, our long-term outlook assumes that Spotify moves to a more optimal capital structure over time, with 20% of the company’s Enterprise
Value with debt holders at a 5% pre-tax rate.
In our view the company’s long-term potential is $188 on a sum-of-the-parts basis using a 3.25x Price/Sales multiple for the 3yr outlook for subscription revenue , a ~40% discount to Netflix based on Spotify’s lower margins and lack of original content, and a 3.0x multiple for the company’s ad-supported segment, a 50% discount to the average Price/Sales multiple for Twitter, Facebook, and Snap due to the company’s lower EBITDA margin.

BornCynic What made me smile was a bloke at the end of the program being interviewed. "Wall Street has realised that too much greed is bad. It has learnt its lesson and will never do that again". All the time he had this big grin on his face...........

Maybe there's some strategy grey to fill the time.

Miss Piggy re FANG, isn't it the case that a tired rally concentrates its upward momentum in a few stocks, in this instance FANG, and if those stocks falter the whole index is in trouble.

Christopher Potts at Kepler's always good.

FATDAZ @BE yes notes from UBS and HSBC have found their way to my in box
11:55 am
BE11:55am

We believe this phase of correction has not yet reached its climax and
that investors should sell market bounces from this point. The final stage
of this correction should be characterised by authentic investor pain &
panic and by a shift into defensive assets, which should be visible by the
end of April. We would start to buy stocks when we see the SPX at the
2500 threshold.
From the beginning, we said that this phase of correction in equity markets
was not to be under-estimated. No, we do not think that it has yet reached
its climax. How will we know?
From the beginning, we said that this phase of correction in equity markets
was not to be under-estimated. No, we do not think that it has yet reached
its climax. How will we know?

wayneJ @TKZ - I fear there are people at AIQ who might argue that AI techniques have been very successful.
BE11:55am

From the beginning, we said that this phase of correction in equity markets
was not to be under-estimated. No, we do not think that it has yet reached
its climax. How will we know?
In our last strategy note we explained that in the final stage of this
correction a shift of investment funds to defensive assets should be
manifest. The evidence of such a transfer is accumulating, but it is not yet
decisive. However, there is another criterion. We should feel it. Sentiment
follows price in the investment industry, which is why consensus thinking is
so worthless. The final stage of a significant market correction of this kind
is almost invariably associated with a degree of investor pain and panic.
Then we should know.
The initial stage of this correction through February was characterised by
the confusion and denial of the investment consensus. The mood turned
cautious in March. In particular, the correction extended to the Nasdaq
growth universe, thereby emphasising its significance. April has begun with
more weakness in this space. Our minimum definition of this correction in
the US equity market has been fulfilled. The S&P500 index has returned to
its long-term moving average in the area between 2500 and 2600.
However, there is not yet authentic investor pain and panic: we think that
this is how this month of April will end.
The reasonable investor is still buying here. We will sell the market bounce
from this point. This correction will climax when the reasonable investor is
too frightened to buy, which requires the perception that the upward trend
in US equity is really compromised. At the least, the 2500 threshold on the
S&P500 has to be visited. The point, of course, is that in an authentic
correction these supposed areas of strong support are frequently broken,
albeit briefly, which is what causes the investor panic.

BE11:56am

We would start to buy stocks when we see the SPX at the 2500 threshold. However,
we will doubtless see this index, and its numerous companions, 2, 3 or 4% lower than
the 2500 threshold if and when investors panic. And they probably will by monthend.
At critical junctures markets do not behave reasonably, not when an entire
industry is so wrong.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Domestic [as in Japanese] investors seem sceptical about the feasibility because of Shire’s large scale.
We received questions on Takeda Pharma's current non-Core assets. While we think
neuroscience and gastrointestinal assets look attractive, we are concerned that Takeda
Pharma currently does not appear to have much expertise in rare diseases, including
haemophilia. On the other hand, some international investors seem to think EPS
accretion could be exciting, although they believe financing could be difficult. We also
received many questions on the possibility of Takeda Pharma listing on an overseas
stock exchange.

TKZ short
BE12:03pm

multiples. If Takeda
were to acquire Shire at the 28 March closing price and 50% were funded by stock
issuance, all else being equal we estimate FY19E Core EPS accretion could be as much
as 87%. In this scenario, we calculate net debt/EBITDA would be 4.7X, which would be
supported by Shire’s strong cash generation capabilities. On the other hand, Takeda
Pharma’s exposure to interest rate risk would be much higher.

BE12:04pm

If Takeda Pharma funded 50% of the potential deal through debt, we estimate net
debt after the combination would reach to ¥5trn, all else equal. The annual dividend
payout could be ¥250bn if Takeda Pharma maintained ¥180/share. Investors may be
concerned about a dividend cut, but we think dividend payments would not be an issue
if we consider cash flow generation. We believe CEO Christophe Weber understands
the importance of maintaining dividends.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

More messy formatting. Sorry.
